section.hand:
To my L. T
re
r 10 De
c
1591

addressleaf.section:
Belgia 1591 10 Decem
b
To my L. Trea
s

page.lettertext:
May it please yo
r
good L. what successe I have had in the
suite of
M
r
Winter
, this bearer his servant can informe
you at large. I had so firme a promise of
Count Maurice
,
as I could not any way request, to have it more in his
favo
r
, to witte, That
e two Italian prisoners
Don Alfonso
D'avalos
, and
Pedro Francesco
should not onely be staied
to redeeme M
r
Winter, but that he himself woulde use
his autoritie, in setting downe what mony should be
paied to
e Captaines, to whome the prisoners apperteined
and that the frindes of M
r
Winter, in disboursing
e
saide mony, should take
e prisoners to themselves, To
this effect he gave his worde, not onely to me, but
to
S
r
Francis Vere
, and that very often, and in sundrie
communications, w
t
suche tokens of willingnes, as I coulde
not desire, to be more assured by his speeches. W
t
all he
desired me to write the same unto her
Ma
tie
from whom I
was moved to will him, That for
e Weakening of the
Enemies purposes in
Fraunce,
there mighte not any pri-
soner of qualitie and service, of those that were taken
in the late encounter at
Arnham,
be released for a
time
time. Moreover I shewed him after, that I had
certefied her Highnes of his honorable dealing towardes
M
r
Winter: and that I was assured it woulde be kindly
accepted, for the speciall services, w
ch
were done by his
Father unto her, and for the hope
at she conceaved,
at
his sonne woulde succeede him in vertu and valo
r
. I told
him besides, that the Gentleman had caused his mony to
be made to
Middlebourgh,
to pay for the prisoners, and
had sent hither to that ende a couple of his servantes.
All this notw
t
standinge upon
e sodaine, w
t
out giving
any notice to S
r
Francis Vere, or to me, he hath released Don
Alfonso and sent him away. The day before his depar-
ture, being secretly informed of this intention of the
Count,
I went of purpose unto him, and signified what I heard,
fol.302v
Belgia: 1591: De
c
putte him in minde of his promise, and of that w
ch
I had writ-
ten to her Ma
tie
upon it. For yo
r
L. I hope receaved
those letters, w
ch
I writte of that matter. His answear was,
at the prisoners had bin long detened, and seing in all this
time they weare able to doe nothing for M
r
Winters delive-
rance, upon suite made unto him by
e
Marquis of Guasto
he had promised to dismisse Don Alfonso: who also pro-
mised upon his hono
r
, that he woulde imploy all his best
frindes and meanes to procure M
r
Winters libertie.
Wherto I replied that if Don Alfonso had bin putte into
our handes, according to promise, there might better
effectes have followed of his endevors: but being used heere
w
t
all curtesie and honor, and being secrettly promised a
great while sins (for so I was advertised by those that
knowe it) that he shoulde be enlarged, there was no hope
that ether he or his frindes would greatly care for M
r
Winter. And as for his promise to doe any thinge
nowe, it had no apparance of any successe. I told him
in conclusion,
at he had given his worde unto me, w
ch
I had
signified unto her Ma
tie
to deliver bothe the prisoners to
M
r
Winters frindes, that they had made over their mony
to certaine marchantes of Middlebourgh, where it had lain a
long time to their very great charges, and that M
r
Winter
by reason of his promise had neglected all other meanes to
procure his redemption. In w
ch
respect I should be sorie
that her Ma
tie
should finde so just a cause to be offended
w
t
his dealing. For mine owne part I could doe noe
otherwise but advertise it home, and leave unto himself
the salving of his hono
r
: wherin I pressed him so neere,
at
he came to this point,
at her Ma
tie
he was sure, would be
pleased w
t
his answear, w
ch
he would signifie himself by
letter unto her: and sent me theruppon
e letter heere
inclosed. Wherof I knowe not the teno
r
, but I have certefied
truly
fol.303r
Belgia 1591 De
c
truly, how the matter hath bin caried. He hath urged
me muche to take the other prisoner, alleaging his credit
w
t
the
D. of Parma
, and
e report of his wealth, for
yelding a rounde ransome, farre above the summe, w
ch
should
be paied for him heere. But forasmuche as bothe
e prisoners, as he himself was persuaded would not
ballance M
r
Winter, in the Enemies account, this other
man alone would serve to litle purpose, unles it were
to make a benefit, to selle him againe: w
ch
I esteemed
as I told him a mechanical consideration, and nothing
to the matter w
ch
was sought by M
r
Winter. And
thus I ended w
t
the Count, whose proceeding in this
matter, doth seeme so very strange, and w
t
out all
excuse, to all that understand it, as I finde him
greatly discommended in every m a ns judgement. And
thus referringe to the bearer w
at
soever is ommitted, I
take my humble leave.
Hage 10 De
c
1591.
